title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the category of crops that has the highest average pesticide cost as cotton and rice.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the category with the greatest energy-based expense in hog farming as fertilizer.
The response identifies the category with the greatest energy-based expense in hog farming as fertilizer.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why there is a difference in electricity costs between beef cattle production and dairy farming, such as the following:

· Dairy farming requires operation of milking machines and/or refrigeration of the milk products, resulting in higher electricity costs than beef production.

The response explains why there is a difference in electricity costs between beef cattle production and dairy farming, such as the following:

· Dairy farming requires operation of milking machines and/or refrigeration of the milk products, resulting in higher electricity costs than beef production.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one environmental problem associated with the energy-based expense that is highest in the production of corn, such as any of the following:

· Runoff of excess fertilizer into nearby waterways leads to eutrophication.

· Fertilizer could leach into ground, contaminating drinking water with nitrates.

· Excessive fertilizer/nitrogen can have toxic effects on soil organisms/disrupt nitrogen cycle.

· Excessive fertilizer can lead to soil acidification and cause chemical burns to crops.

· Fertilizer increases the growth of weeds that could compete with corn crops.

The response describes one environmental problem associated with the energy-based expense that is highest in the production of corn, such as one of the following:

· Runoff of excess fertilizer into nearby waterways leads to eutrophication.

· Fertilizer could leach into ground, contaminating drinking water with nitrates.

· Excessive fertilizer/nitrogen can have toxic effects on soil organisms/disrupt nitrogen cycle.

· Excessive fertilizer can lead to soil acidification and cause chemical burns to crops.

· Fertilizer increases the growth of weeds that could compete with corn crops.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how a shift from cattle farming to wheat farming will affect the ecological footprint of the farm, such as any of the following:

· Greenhouse gases emitted during beef cattle production contribute to climate change and/or growing wheat captures greenhouse gases from the atmosphere and reduces climate change.

· Ecological footprint will be reduced because raising beef uses larger amounts of grain, water and land than raising wheat.

· Based on the 10% rule, the wheat farm will decrease the ecological footprint. Growing plants has a lower ecological footprint than beef cattle production because livestock feed on crops and the 10% rule approximates that only 10% of energy is transferred from one tropic level to another.

· Switching from raising livestock to growing a crop, there would be reduced overgrazing/less soil compaction/etc., which would reduce the ecological footprint of the farm.

The response explains how a shift from cattle farming to wheat farming will affect the ecological footprint of the farm, such as one of the following:

· Greenhouse gases emitted during beef cattle production contribute to climate change and/or growing wheat captures greenhouse gases from the atmosphere and reduces climate change.

· Ecological footprint will be reduced because raising beef uses larger amounts of grain, water and land than raising wheat.

· Based on the 10% rule, the wheat farm will decrease the ecological footprint. Growing plants has a lower ecological footprint than beef cattle production because livestock feed on crops and the 10% rule approximates that only 10% of energy is transferred from one tropic level to another.

· Switching from raising livestock to growing a crop, there would be reduced overgrazing/less soil compaction/etc., which would reduce the ecological footprint of the farm.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why a wheat farmer installing PV MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaaa baaaaaaaaapeGaaeiuaiaabAfaaaa@39C5@ solar panels at the farm would or would not be an effective long-term approach for reducing energy costs, such as any of the following:

· It would not be an effective long-term approach. Relatively the amount of money spent on electricity is low and a shift to solar panels would impact a very small portion of energy costs.

· This would not be an effective approach. The wheat farmer could be in an area that does not have sufficient sunlight to provide enough energy to be a good long-term solution to reduce costs and to offset installation and ongoing maintenance costs.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how conservation landscaping techniques can reduce home electricity consumption during hot summers, such as any of the following:

· Placing trees to promote shade in strategic areas can reduce air conditioning costs.

· Increasing plant coverage around house will minimize solar energy absorption that re-radiates as heat from bare ground or concrete, which could minimize electrical use for cooling.

title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how keeping hogs outside in temperatures that drop below freezing (0 °C MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaaa baaaaaaaaapeGaaeiSaiaaboeaaaa@3A12@ ) in the winter would likely impact the feed requirements of the hogs, such as any of the following:

· The hogs would need to consume large quantities of feed in the winter to offset heat loss. The diet would need to be adjusted to increase the concentration of nutrients/average daily feed intake.

· The hogs would need to consume large quantities of feed in the winter to maintain normal body temperature. The diet would need to be adjusted to increase the concentration of nutrients/average daily feed intake.
